pr_title: Don't Allocate Redundant Pages in BigArrays

timeline.message:
Don't Allocate Redundant Pages in BigArrays

The oversize algorithm was allocating more pages than necessary to accomodate `minTargetSize`.
An example would be that a 16k page size and 15k `minTargetSize` would result in a new size of 32k (2 pages).
The difference between the minimum number of necessary pages and the estimated size then keeps growing as sizes increase.

I don't think there is much value in preemptively allocating pages by oversizing aggressively since the behavior of
the system is quite different from that of a single array where oversizing avoids copying
once the minimum target size is more than a single page.

Relates #60173 which lead me to this when `BytesStreamOutput` would allocate a large number of never used
pages during serialization of repository metadata.

timeline.bodyText: This now doesn't always return a multiple of pageSize; is that deliberate? Maybe it's ok, but if it is ok then why do we put effort into rounding newSize up to the next multiple of pageSize in the else branch?
timeline.author: DaveCTurner

replies.bodyText:
This now doesn't always return a multiple of pageSize; is that deliberate?

This was the case before as well. For small allocations (those for which Arrays.oversize does return less than a page) we return the result of oversize.

Maybe it's ok, but if it is ok then why do we put effort into rounding newSize up to the next multiple of pageSize in the else branch?

I think the reasoning is that we only want to use a full page for allocations above a certain size. But once we get to large allocations we only want to use full pages.
For small pages I mostly retained the behavior here. Except for the case of say 15k with 16k pages, where previously oversize would spit out something like 17k and we'd then go for 2 pages, whereas now we go for a single page.
But as long as oversize stays below a full page in size the behavior should not change with this PR.

timeline.bodyText: I wonder if resizeInPlace took a number of pages instead of a size and we only used oversize for when the size is less than a page. We may not need this method at all in that case. I just feel like we're doing something like (pages + 1) * pageSize / pageSize and it feels clumsy.
